nytimes_articles.headline: Fear of Condom Ads
nytimes_articles.abstract:
We're 15 years into the AIDS epidemic, but three of the major TV networks --  ABC, CBS and NBC -- still do not accept paid advertising for condoms. The reason? Viewers would be offended, they say. 

     Fox will not run a paid condom ad that advocates birth control, but it will air ads that carry a safer-sex message. And while it has run ads in the past, it has not done so in two years.

Dikakis' (The Movie)
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Recently, a copy of the shooting script of Oliver Stone's next film, "Dukakis," was delivered to my office by a man wearing green fatigues. He seemed to have a slight Cuban accent. 

     Filmed in total secrecy, this movie, the logical successor to the director's  explosive "JFK" and his corrosive "Nixon," reveals the enigmatic former Presidential candidate in a startling and potentially commercial way. Here are excerpts.

Divorce, New York Style
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Invoking Section 170 of New York State's domestic relations law, each year some 28,000 unhappy husbands and wives bring their marital and family disputes to the New York State Supreme Court. 

     Section 170 speaks of "cruel and inhuman treatment" between spouses. Little did litigants imagine that, as of Jan. 1, they would be subjected to even more such treatment -- this from an unlikely source, the judicial system itself.

Turbulence
nytimes_articles.abstract: HARD LANDING The Epic Contest for Power and Profits That Plunged the Airlines Into Chaos. By Thomas Petzinger Jr. Illustrated. 520 pp. New York: Times Business Books/Random House. $30.    AS the invective grew louder between labor and management at Eastern Airlines in 1983, Frank Borman heard a frightening rumor. Mr. Borman, the chief executive of Eastern and former astronaut, received information that someone had put out a contract on his life. The F.B.I. advised Mr. Borman to wear a bulletproof vest.  He also strapped a 9-millimeter automatic pistol to his ankle and began a crash  course in how to use it. Over the next few days, he went everywhere with a young man whose presence alongside him, he was told, would deter a mob hit.

NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN;Will Yogurt Replace Coffee at L.I.R.R. Station?
nytimes_articles.abstract:
During rush hour, knots of commuters stand in front of an unnamed snack bar inside the Long Island Rail Road's Flatbush station that is affectionately known as Mike's. They come in the morning to grab a cup of coffee on their way to the  adjoining subway lines. For trips home, they pick up boxes of warm popcorn. 

     Those scenes may soon change. Mike's is in danger of closing.

NEW JERSEY & CO.;From Discounts to Diaspora: A Bazaar Starts to Fold Its Tent
nytimes_articles.abstract:
A handwritten sign in Craft Plus says "Clearance Store Wide." 

     For the proprietor, Rebecca Mutahi, storewide is an 8-by-10-foot stall she rents at U.S. No. 1 Flea Market & Antiques. The clearance is necessary because the market -- an everything-under-the-sun bazaar that may be the state's largest indoor venue for independent discount merchants -- will soon be torn down to make room for a 16-screen movie theater.

VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;After Dinner, a Communication Taste Test
nytimes_articles.abstract:
FOR the last few years, I have been conducting secret research. The results are intriguing and illuminate something fundamental about communication design.  And like some of the best findings, this one was based largely on a chance event -- my discovery of an old set of children's blocks. 

     The unwitting subjects of my study have been dinner guests over the last few  years. As any host-researcher knows, there is an odd gap between the time the table is cleared of the main course and when coffee and dessert are served. A few years ago, I noticed a set of wooden blocks on a shelf and set them on the dining table so guests could play with them to pass away this time.

nytimes_articles.headline: RACING TO THE TOP
Architect of Gains In Child Care
nytimes_articles.abstract:
COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew P. O'Rourke knows first hand what Sally Ziegler, a children's advocate, has meant to families in Westchester. In an early encounter, she strode into the 1981 county budget hearing Mr. O'Rourke presided  over followed by nearly 1,000 parents. Ms. Ziegler's group testified past midnight, a filibuster of sorts, which prompted Mr. O'Rourke, then head of the County Board of Legislators, to return $1 million the Board had originally cut from the child-care budget. 

     If his budget balancing efforts were stymied by Ms. Ziegler at the time, all  is now forgiven. As master of ceremonies for her retirement dinner, Mr. O'Rourke praised Ms. Ziegler, who left the helm of the Westchester Child Care Council at  the end of 1995, for her tenacity. Sometimes on opposite ends of issues, Mr. O'Rourke said she had been a hard person to say no to. After 30 years of public  service, he said, "Sally leaves a legacy of dedication to thousands of children  and families."

ON THE MAP;A Room for Quiet Meditation in Keyport
nytimes_articles.abstract:
In the 15 years since Theodore J. Miller declared his historic 18-room Keyport house open to the public, the house has become a mecca for art and culture lovers in central New Jersey. They admire its eclectic decorations, Federal architecture and large, informal garden. 

     But few are aware of yet another facet to this extraordinary house, named the Master's Octave: a Wednesday night meditation circle. Inside the french doors, a dozen or more friends sit peacefully in a loose circle. They clear their minds,  and, Ted Miller says, receive visits and teachings of "truth" from ascendant beings, like the Archangel Gabriel, the Virgin Mary and Jesus.

VOWS;Anne Gilbert and Gordon Goldstein
DINING OUT;Where Hot Really Does Mean Incendiary
Counterresponse To College President
Save Your Breath, Sisters
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Don't trust everything the press tells you about how black women think. Lots  of us went to see "Waiting to Exhale" expecting to enjoy a film about four black women friends coping with life and relationships, yet could not relate to the shallow, adolescent nonsense we saw on the screen. We were not even entertained. I went with a group of friends, all of us professional women, single and married. Mostly, we were upset and disappointed. Not one of us saw a realistic portrayal of our lives. 

     I'm 43, single and searching for true love. What I saw was not women talking  about love or the meaning of marriage or partnership, but women being obsessive  about men, material success and petty competition with other women, especially white women. No doubt it helps crossover appeal to set up a stereotypically racist and sexist conflict between white women and black women competing to see  who will win the man in the end. In the original novel, by Terry McMillan, competition of this sort does not have center stage.

SOAPBOX;Good for Business, Not New Jersey
nytimes_articles.abstract:
A FAMILIAR roadside billboard offers this message: "A Better Business Climate Means More Jobs." It's a catchy little phrase, a variation on the old adage, "What's Good for Business Is Good for America." They both have the ring of common sense. But last week's bombshell from AT&T; -- the decision to lay off 40,000 employees, including as many as 7,000 in New Jersey -- shows how wrong common sense can be. 

     Over the last year, New Jersey corporations have re-engineered hundreds of jobs out of existence, while hundreds more have been lost when companies moved out of state. The recent closing of the Wonder Bread bakery in East Brunswick alone cost the state 500 jobs.

Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY;Ibarra and Beyond
nytimes_articles.abstract: If it is evil to care too much for things that have neither mind nor heart,  then I am evil," Harriet Doerr writes in the first of the 15 pieces of memoir and short fiction in THE TIGER IN THE GRASS: Stories and Other Inventions (Viking, $19.95). This is far too hyperbolic a statement. Ms. Doerr does have a  sure and elegant hand when it comes to describing flora and fauna and the houses in California and Mexico where she has lived. But with her keen attention to detail in matters of character and emotion, she demonstrates a compassionate spirit that is anything but evil. Using an episodic structure similar to those in her novels, "Stones From Ibarra" and "Consider This, Senora," this new book allows Ms. Doerr to contemplate certain events from the nearly nine decades of her life, even as she returns us to the locales made familiar in her fiction. Writing with admirable simplicity, she recalls spending sublime childhood summers at the beach, knitting a muffler for an American soldier in France (who  sent her a much-cherished thank-you note) and going off to Smith College in 1927. There are also memories of being widowed at 65 after 42 years of marriage  and then going back to college, and of helplessly standing by as her son began to succumb to cancer. Several of the short stories, set in Ibarra, reacquaint readers with Sara and Richard Everton, who were introduced in Ms. Doerr's first  book. Others explore different parts of rural Mexico. Like the matilija poppies  of Ms. Doerr's youth, "whose crushed tissue-paper petals unfolded every June into white flowers as big as a child's face," these previously uncollected short works are strikingly pure and radiant.   RUTH COUGHLIN

PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: January 7, 1996
TEACHING TEACHERS;Getting Minority Students Turned On to Teaching
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Jessica Benitez Elliott almost didn't become a teacher. All her life she had  heard the adage, "Those who can, do. Those who can't, teach." So Ms. Elliott pursued, albeit miserably, a career as a psychologist. Then in 1994, while completing her master's in psychology at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore,  she spotted a flier offering paid teaching internships for minority students. 

      That's how Ms. Elliott's career took a detour and why, on a Friday afternoon, she was trasforming a second grade classroom at the private Park School of Baltimore into a bazaar of Hispanic culture. Hispanic art and storybooks were diplayed along with magazines featuring Hispanic productsandmodels. Students tasted mango nectar and galleta cookies (similar to  shortbread), popular in Puerto Rico, where Ms. Elliott grew up.

Commercial Property/Thinking Green;Balancing Environmental Activism and the Market
nytimes_articles.abstract:
EVEN the best building designs are often gravely disabled before they are born," observes Amory Lovins, co-founder and director of the Rocky Mountain Institute, an environmental research organization based in Snowmass, Colo. 

     Mr. Lovins cites "perverse incentives" that steer the development, financing, design and construction of commercial buildings away from energy conservation and environmental sustainability and toward solutions that are formulaic and cheap to build.

STUDENT LIFE;On the Net, a Network for News
nytimes_articles.abstract:
After a recent list compiled by four Cornell freshmen of "75 reasons why women shouldn't have freedom of speech" was distributed to tens of thousands of  people via the inernet, students at several other colleges as well as Cornell read about it in their campus newspapers. But unlike most out-of-town news that  appears in university publications, the articles about the misogynist E-mail message weren't taken from The Associated Press or anyother major wire service run especially for camus new. 

      In an age when an increasing number of Americans are embracing the convenience and efficiency of electronic mail, college newspaper editors have found that the new technology enables their papers to cover events from other schools with a regularity that was never before possible.

nytimes_articles.abstract:
Last week, six men stood around the counter of a deli in the center of Little Pakistan, smoking rich Rothman's cigarettes and discussing the political future  of their growing community. 

     "We are trying to create a voting bloc here," Mohammed Jamil Aziz said. "In less than five years, we will be able to put in our own candidate."

GOLF;O'Meara's Perfect Day Ends in a 4-Stroke Lead
nytimes_articles.abstract:
As a kid growing up in nearby Mission Viejo, Mark O'Meara used to work as a spotter for ABC-TV, coming down to La Costa Resort and Spa to work at the 17th hole where he would watch Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus and Lee Trevino work their magic in the Tournament of Champions. 

     He never thought that some 20 years later the best players in golf would be spotting him four strokes going into the final round of the Mercedes Championships, the modern-day version of the T of C.

APPEARANCES;Getting Vertical
Zacatecas, built by the Silver
nytimes_articles.abstract:
ZACATECAS reminds me of Lucy in the Wordsworth poem "She Dwelt Among the Untrodden Ways": "a maid who there were none to praise/and very few to love." If Zacatecas isn't loved nearly as much as it should be, it's only because it's relatively undiscovered. 

     There are two reasons for this: first, being 375 miles northwest of Mexico City, on the northern edge of the central plateau, it is out of the way; and second, Zacatecas has not been overzealous in making the world aware of its virtues.

nytimes_articles.headline: For Homeless, a Long, Cold Winter Ahead
Jobs Die So Companies May Live
nytimes_articles.abstract:
It may be cold comfort to the managers of AT&T; who will be laid off this year, but I'd rather be in their shoes than in those of similar managers in France. True, the French Government backed down last month from changes that would have made the vast state-owned companies more efficient at the cost of layoffs. But this simply assures the further decline of these companies and an inevitable increase in the already high French unemployment rate. 

     At least in the United States, laid-off middle managers have a better chance  of finding a new job. This prospect in no way reduces the pain of those AT&T; employees who must now seek new careers -- 40,000 in all, including those who accepted voluntary buyouts and employees in subsidiaries. But it does mean that  they will be moving more quickly to new jobs and opportunities rather than denying an inescapable economic fact.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Boycott That Changed Dr. King's Life
nytimes_articles.abstract:
By the time the Montgomery Improvement Association chose the 26-year-old Martin Luther King Jr. as its leader, the hours-old bus boycott by the black citizens of Montgomery, Ala., was already an overwhelming success. King would later write that his unanticipated call to leadership "happened so quickly that I did not have time to think it through. It is probable that if I had, I would have declined the nomination." 

     Although press reports at the time focused on his inspiring oratory, King was actually a reluctant leader of a movement initiated by others. (The boycott began on Dec. 5, 1955.) His subsequent writings and private correspondence reveal a man whose inner doubts sharply contrast with his public persona. In the early days of his involvement, King was troubled by telephone threats, discord within the black community and Montgomery's "get tough" policy, to which King attributed his jailing on a minor traffic violation. One night, as he considered ways to "move out of the picture without appearing a coward," he began to pray aloud and, at that moment, "experienced the presence of the Divine as I had never experienced Him before."

HERS;Doing The Right Thing
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THERE WERE ONLY SEVEN REGISTERED Democrats in the small Massachusetts town where I grew up. The night Jack Kennedy was elected President, all seven of them got drunk and did the twist at the railroad station, so I naturally thought that, aside from having better notions about the role of government, Democrats had more fun than Republicans. That insight alone turned me into a Democrat, and in my numerous recountings of the episode, I can't imagine why it didn't work for my daughter, Caitlin. 

     Not long after her 18th birthday, Caitlin told me she had registered to vote. But when she told me she was a Republican, I felt faint.

nytimes_articles.abstract: A GARDEN STORY By Leon Whiteson. 168 pp. Boston: Faber & Faber. $18.95.    LEON WHITESON'S book belongs to a genus that is coming back into fashion after a dormant spell: the miniature memoir, almost an extended essay, partial but intense, more rumination than narrative. It is not unusual for a book of this type to have a presiding metaphor or resonating motif. The writer tours himself, and takes the reader with him, while ostensibly looking out from that self onto its preoccupations. "In Patagonia," by Bruce Chatwin, is a model of the type, fabulously self-absorbed but exhilaratingly inclusive.

VOICES: VIEWPOINT;Look, Uncle Sam, No Form 1040's
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE worst part about the American income tax system is filling out long and complex tax forms -- the sort millions of Americans began receiving from the Internal Revenue Service last week. The I.R.S. already has most of the information we have to enter on numerous forms and schedules. If the United States followed the lead of Britain and many other European countries, most of us could avoid this annual burden. At the same time, the Government would pick up more revenue at less expense. 

     How? Through a return-free tax system based on withholding at the source with lower rates. With a few systemic adjustments, the United States could have a less burdensome income tax system that would be simpler and fairer to most taxpayers.

wiki_events.headline: An Antonov An-32 cargo aircraft crashes into a crowded market in Kinshasa, Zaire, killing up to 223 people on the ground; two of six crew members are also killed.

pages.title: Antonov An-32
pages.description: Airliner and military tactical transport aircraft by Antonov
pages.abstract: The Antonov An-32 is a turboprop twin-engined military transport aircraft. Its first flight was in July 1976 and displayed at the 1977 Paris Air Show. It is oriented towards flying in adverse weather conditions, and was produced from 1980 to 2012, and remains in service. It is the fourth member of the Antonov An-24 family, succeeding the An-24, An-30 and An-26, and coming before the cancelled An-132.

pages.title: 1996 Air Africa Antonov An-32 crash
pages.abstract: On 8 January 1996, a Moscow Airways Antonov An-32B operating on behalf of Air Africa overran the runway at N'Dolo Airport after attempting to take off overloaded. The aircraft was flying from Kinshasa to Kahemba, Zaire. The aircraft ploughed into Kinshasa's Simbazikita street market. Four of the six crew of the aircraft survived the accident. On the ground, however, it is estimated that there were between 225 and 348 fatalities, with more than 500 people injured. It was the deadliest aviation accident in African history until the 2018 Algerian Air Force Ilyushin Il-76 crash, the deadliest to occur in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and the deadliest accident in terms of ground fatalities, superseded only by the intentional crashes of American Airlines Flight 11 and United Airlines Flight 175 in the September 11 attacks.

pages.title: Kinshasa
pages.description: Capital and most populous city of DR Congo
pages.abstract: Kinshasa, formerly named Léopoldville from 1881–1966, is the capital and largest city of the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Kinshasa is one of the world's fastest-growing megacities, with an estimated population of 17.8 million in 2024. It is the most densely populated city in the DRC, the third-most populous city and third-largest metropolitan area in Africa, and the world's twenty-second most populous city and fourth-most populous capital city. It is the leading economic, political, and cultural center of the DRC, housing several industries including manufacturing, telecommunications, banking, and entertainment. The city also hosts some of the DRC's significant institutional buildings, such as the People's Palace, Palace of the Nation, Court of Cassation, Constitutional Court, African Union City, Marble Palace, Martyrs Stadium, Government House, Kinshasa Financial Center, and other national departments and agencies.

pages.title: Zaire
pages.abstract: Zaire, officially the Republic of Zaire, was a state in central Africa from 1971 to 1997. It was, by area, the third-largest country in Africa after Sudan and Algeria, and the 11th-largest country in the world from 1965 to 1991. With a population of over 23 million, Zaire was the most populous Francophone country in Africa. Zaire was strategically important to the West during the Cold War, particularly the U.S., as a counterbalance to Soviet influence in Africa. The U.S. and its allies supported the Mobutu Regime (1965–1997) with military and economic aid to prevent the spread of communism.
